title-group.article-title: Tourism Market Segmentation Based on Price Sensitivity
title-group.subtitle: Finding Similar Price Preferences on Tourism Activities

author-notes.corresp: Lorenzo Masiero, Institute for Economic Research, Via Maderno, 24 - CP 4361, CH-6904 Lugano Email: lorenzo.masiero@usi.ch

abstract.p: This article builds on the double role of the effect of prices on the choice of tourism activities: not only is it the sole component of the destination marketing mix that represents revenue but also a determinant factor in tourist choice. On this account, identifying patterns of tourists with different degrees of sensitivities to prices would help destinations design an appropriate bundle of activities and have a clear definition of the segment they should try to attract. Accordingly, the objective of this article is to identify tourist segments from individual price sensitivities to activities. The results show—although price has a dissuasive influence on the choice of activities—a differentiated effect (as this dissuasiveness is not general for all individuals); this heterogeneous responsiveness to price supports its use as a segmentation criterion. In the empirical application, four segments are found with significantly different price sensitivities.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The literature has devoted special attention to the effect of price on destination choice (Haider and Ewing 1990; Morey, Shaw, and Rowe 1991; Eymann and Ronning 1992; Morley 1994a, 1994b; Dubin 1998; Train 1998; Riera 2000; Siderelis and Moore 1998). However, once tourists are at the destination, the price of the activities available also becomes a salient attribute to determine their behavior. In this regard, knowledge of individual sensitivities to activity prices permits the identification of groups of people defined in terms of their predisposition to pay for a set of activities.

Although market segmentation is extensively applied in the tourism industry (Sarigöllü and Huang 2005) and intensively analyzed by tourism academics through the use of demographics (Mudambi and Baum 1997), behavior (Pritchard and Howard 1997; Laesser and Crouch 2006), psychographics (Sirakaya, Uysal, and Yoshioka 2003), and benefits (Kastenholz, Davis, and Paul 1999), the formation of segments through price sensitivities is scarcer (e.g., Petrick 2005), let alone the use of price sensitivities related to activities at destination.

Certainly, the analysis of individual price sensitivities to tourism activities has received less attention, although it is an element of major importance: on one hand, destination managers look for development through the use of resources and creation of activities that improve the destination’s well-being. Consequently, identifying patterns of tourists with different degrees of sensitivity to prices would help them design an appropriate bundle of activities and have a clear definition of the segments the destination should try to attract. On the other hand, tourists obtain pleasure from leisure activities that they take part in at the destination, but they balance the pleasure obtained from the activities against the amount of money that has to be paid. Therefore, not only is it relevant to know who is interested in a specific activity but also to learn how much an individual is predisposed to pay to partake in it.

In this vein, the objective of this article is to find tourist segments from individual activity price sensitivities. For this purpose, the article is organized as follows: the next section reviews the importance of segmenting tourist markets through price sensitivities; the third section covers the design of the investigation, describing the data and methodology; the fourth section presents the results and their discussion; and the final section summarizes the conclusions.

sec.title: Segmentation and Individual Price Sensitivities
sec.p: Segmentation is critical to the marketing strategies of tourism organizations (Bloom 2004; Chen 2003), on account of tourists’ search for service tailored to their varying needs, consequent to their heterogeneity. Accordingly, Dolnicar and Grün (2008) indicate, tourists do not “seek the same benefits from a destination, have the same expectations, undertake the same vacation activities, and perceive the same vacation components as attractive.” Therefore, market segmentation strategies have become the norm to find markets with similar behaviors so that tourism companies can adapt their offer (Kotler 2003). Certainly, a strategic approach based on market segmentation and customer satisfaction is a critical long-term tool to destination marketers (Jeng and Fesenmaier 2002; Dolnicar 2004; Laesser and Crouch 2006), which is regarded to allow them to increase profitability (Dolnicar and Leisch 2003).

A core aspect to look at in order to segment the market is decision making (Bronner and de Hoog 1985): if the way people make their purchase selections is observed (e.g., choosing a destination as well as selecting a specific set of activities), we can determine the main dimensions with more influence on these decisions, which ultimately would allow managers find the way to maintain a long-term relationship with their selected target groups. Even though some research has focused on decision making to detect segments (Hsieh et al. 1997; Decrop and Snelders 2004), their analyses are carried out at a segment level rather than an individual level. Alternatively, we analyze individual choice decisions and focus on the estimation of one of the most determinant variables, which is price.

Prices in tourism are difficult to deal with on account of their analysis and impact on demand: in terms of their analysis, Crouch (1992, 1994) refers to it as a complex and vexatious issue, and regarding their impact, Dwyer et al. (2000) suggest that “changing costs in particular destinations relative to others are regarded as the most important economic influence on destination shares of total travel abroad.” It is no wonder that Cooper et al. (2008) describe the pricing decision as the hardest to make in the marketing mix. In this regard, the literature does not reach a consensus on the influence of prices on tourism decisions. In general terms, demand for tourism products is that of an ordinary good, in such a way that price increments diminish consumption (Smith 1995), meaning that price is considered as a factor which reduces the utility of an alternative. However, value for money, which compares the amount spent with the quality of installations and service, is central in tourism and, as such, has been described as a critical indicator of competitiveness (Stevens 1992), an element creating positive behavioral intentions such as repurchase (Petrick, Morais, and Norman 2001; Petrick and Backman 2002; Petrick 2004; Chen and Tsai 2007; He and Song 2009), and as a satisfaction-generator (Bojanic 1996; Chen and Tsai 2008). Bojanic (1996) indicates that prices and quality are the two basic elements used to form strategies to gain a competitive edge, and through the relative perceived value concept it is possible to offer comparable quality at a comparable price, offer superior quality at a premium price, or offer inferior quality at a discounted price. At this point, the dual function of price–value perceptions emerges (Murphy and Pritchard 1997), as price can be an index of the amount of sacrifice the individual has to incur to consume the product as well as the level of quality that the individual expects (Dodds et al. 1991). Dodds and Monroe (1985) show that this dual effect will affect people’s predisposition to buy: the higher the prices, the greater the perceived quality and therefore the higher the willingness to purchase, but also the higher the sacrifices and the lesser the preparedness to buy.

In this vein, Erickson and Johansson (1985) state that the role price plays in a consumer’s evaluation of product alternatives is multidimensional, and they distinguish between the reduction of wealth because of high prices (prices as a constraint), and the information on product quality these high prices convey (prices as a product attribute), in line with the dual function of price–value perceptions (Murphy and Pritchard 1997). This multidimensional view of prices leads to increased awareness of the importance of price implications, since the role of different price dimensions varies between consumers and product types, and recognition that complex pricing schemes may be a necessity for particular situations (Gijsbrechts 1993). In other words, the measurement of the effect of price is not an easy task and a host of complicating factors emerges, such as consumer heterogeneity.

When it comes to the choice of tourism activities, it is important to note that tourists obtain pleasure from activities that they participate in at destinations, but they have to compare the pleasure obtained with the cost they have to incur, that is, their prices. Therefore, the price appears to be a decisive element again once they arrive at the destination. Also, as destinations’ financial income is mostly determined by the price paid, knowing the effect that the price of activities exerts on their selection is fundamental. What is more, if individual sensitivities to price were estimated, groups of tourists with different sensitivities could be found, making it possible for a destination to identify the best segments according to individual activity price sensitivities. In this regard, Dolnicar (2004) qualifies it as being of utmost importance to analyze the market structure as thoroughly as possible to detect the best market segments in terms of their attractiveness.

Therefore, considering the existence of tourist heterogeneity and the importance of establishing close relationships with tourists to provide tailored products once they get to the destination, we attempt to find segments according to individual price sensitivities to tourism activities, in a choice framework.

sec.title: Data
sec.p: The investigation of tourists’ preferences toward hypothetical bundle of activities (i.e., tourist cards) at the destination has been carried out through a stated preference (SP) experiment conducted in Ticino, Switzerland, during summer 2010, and within a larger study aimed at investigating the potential for a regional tourist card. According to Bieger and Laesser (2002), Switzerland is an interesting case in terms of maturity and because it has the highest per capita international travel activity in the world.

Tourists were faced with a set of hypothetical choice situations generated according to a fractional factorial orthogonal experiment design comprising five attributes with three levels each, where four attributes refer to activities undertaken by tourists and the fifth attribute represents the price of the hypothetical tourist card. Table 1 describes the attributes and attribute levels considered in the study.

list-item.p: 20% discount on sports and renting sport equipment
Free boat trips on the lake

sec.p: To define the four attributes associated with tourist activities, a first wave of a field survey was conducted among 586 tourists visiting Ticino,1 with questions on demographics, trip characteristics, motivations, activities undertaken, and attitudes toward tourist cards. As tourist cards usually involve a set of activities offered at the destination, the activities data were, first, investigated in depth and, second, used for the construction of the stated choice experiment. In particular, a principal components analysis performed on the 12 activities investigated in the survey resulted in four components with three variables (i.e., activities) each. Successively, the four components were labeled accordingly and used as attributes for the stated choice experiment whereas the activities within each component were used as attribute levels and treated according to the conventional effect coding format.

As for price, the attribute levels were selected mainly on the basis of the prices for existing tourist cards in different markets. Furthermore, once the minimum and maximum price thresholds (i.e., 30 and 60 CHF) were identified, a third level was introduced (i.e., 45 CHF) resulting in a price attribute described by three levels. In particular, having three levels for the price attribute allows for potential investigation of nonlinearities in the marginal utility, still ensuring, however, a consistent range between the levels.2

As for the scenario of the experiment, the validity of the card was set to one day (i.e., 24 hours) and the free access to public transport service was included in the price of the hypothetical tourist card. Figure 1 shows an example of a choice card presented to tourists interviewed.

Each respondent had to state his preference among three options, namely card A, card B, and none of the two cards. In the case that the selected option was none of the two cards, the respondent was successively asked to state his preference only between card A and card B. The following analysis is based on the former scenario (i.e., the choice among card A, card B, and none of the two cards).

Along with the choice experiment, tourists were also asked to answer a set of preselected questions concerning sociodemographics, tourist behavior, motivations (measured according to a 4-point Likert-type scale—not at all important, rather unimportant, rather important, very important) and activity participation frequency (measured according to a 4-point Likert-type scale—never, once, few times, every day). A detailed list is provided in the Results section (Table 4). In particular, the interest for sociodemographics was oriented to nationalities and age classes, whereas for tourist behavior the study focused on type of accommodation, number of nights, first visitors, transportation mode, and holiday budget for activities at destination. As for the questions on motivations, they refer to push motivations (i.e., those individual factors that push to travel), which were mainly adapted from Yoon and Uysal (2005), who propose a review for both push and pull tourist motivations. Finally, a list of the most relevant activities at the destination was created and presented to respondents in order to investigate their activity participation.

The stated choice experiment was presented to respondents during the second wave of the field survey and conducted by face-to-face interviews3 held in nine major touristic locations and performed by three interviewers, three days per week over one month (from mid-August 2010 to mid-September 2010). In total, 261 valid interviews were collected, with each respondent facing 12 choice situations, resulting in 3,132 choice observations.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: The analysis consisted of two stages: (1) estimation of individual price sensitivities through a logit model with random coefficients (i.e., a mixed logit model) and (2) segment formation.

Discrete choice models, such as mixed logit models, belong to the random utility class of models (McFadden 1974) and, in the analysis of the demand, are currently used in a wide range of research areas, including marketing, transportation, housing, and environmental economics.4 Indeed, several choice modeling applications have been growing in tourism as well (Crouch and Louviere 2001). Most of the attention has been oriented to destination choice with the use of experimental data, stated preference data,5 and revealed data (see, e.g., Morley 1994b; Scarpa and Thiene 2005; LaMondia, Snell, and Bhat 2010). In this context, Nicolau and Más (2006) provide an exhaustive review of the empirical evidence of probabilistic models for destination choice with both revealed and stated preferences data. However, choice modeling applications can also be found in specific tourism categories, such as convention site selection (Crouch and Louviere 2004), heritage attractions (Apostolakis and Jaffry 2005), discretionary spending and tourism consumption (Crouch et al. 2007), tourists’ preferences for natural environment (Brau 2008), winter sport tourism (Unbehaun, Probstl, and Haider 2008), and space tourism (Crouch et al. 2009). Regarding activities at destination, Dellaert, Borgers, and Timmermans (1995) propose a stated choice experiment for modeling urban tourists’ choices of activity packages in different periods of a hypothetical weekend in Paris and without considering a price attribute. However, to our knowledge, there are no previous studies proposing market segmentation based on a stated choice experiment for modeling tourists’ choice of hypothetical tourist cards.

sec.title: Stage I: Individual price sensitivities
sec.p: To estimate the individual parameters (price sensitivities) of a mixed logit model, we apply Bayesian estimation methods in the context of discrete choice. In particular, the utility function, associated with respondent n for alternative j in choice situation s, is typically assumed to be linear in parameters, and represented as follows:

where εnjs is the random term that is Independent and Identically Distributed (IID) extreme value type 1. The mixed logit class of model allows estimation of taste heterogeneity by specification of a density function for the standard deviation of the estimated coefficient. Formally, the random coefficient takes the following functional form:

where βk is the sample mean, vnk is the individual specific heterogeneity with mean zero and standard deviation one, and σk is the standard deviation of βnk around βk, assumed normally distributed. Assuming a significant heterogeneity around the mean value, the individual estimates can be obtained through the concept of the Bayes Identity, which states as follows:
where yn indicates the alternative j chosen by respondent n. Starting from the Bayes identity it is possible to formulate the conditional density of the random coefficient, which result as follows:

where Ln is the simulated log likelihood and Pn is the probability associated with respondent n choosing alternative j. The conditional expectation is then derived, resulting in the following function:
As the integral does not have a closed form, the individual price coefficient estimates need to be simulated as follows:
where r = 1, …, R is the number of draws used in the simulation process for the estimation of the parameters. In the present study, 500 Halton draws6 have been used.

sec.title: Stage II: Segment formation
sec.p: Once we obtain the parameter estimates for each individual, we proceed to construct segments with similar preferences by focusing on the attribute “price.” To this end, we apply cluster analysis (Ward’s minimum variance hierarchical algorithm) to the matrix of parameters. The Ward Algorithm is used to form hierarchical groups of mutually exclusive subsets (Ward 1963). Given a number of h sets, this algorithm reduces them to h − 1 mutually exclusive sets by taking into account the union of all possible h(h − 1)/2 pairs and choosing the union that has the maximum value for the objective function. In short, this procedure seeks to minimize the sum of squares of any two potential clusters that can be formed at each stage. The final number of segments is reached when the segments observed explain at least 65% of the global variance and, when another segment is added, the increase in the total variance is less than 5% (Lewis and Thomas 1990). In the opinion of Grande and Abascal (2009) and Gené (2002), this is the most appropriate method when using variables derived from previous statistical procedures; and Sorensen (2003) indicates that this method is regarded as very efficient. In addition, we apply an analysis of variance (ANOVA) to confirm the segments obtained, that is, to validate the existence of differences in the preference structures of the individuals.

sec.title: Estimation of the Individual Parameters
sec.p: Firstly, we estimate the price coefficients for each individual, which is determinant of tourism activity choice, using mixed logit models. The global results for the variable “price” that represent the preferences of an average individual are as follows: it shows a parameter equal to −0.0398 (t statistic = −9.58) and a standard deviation standing at 0.041 (t-statistic =14.73), both significant at 0.001 (for the illustration of the entire model estimates, see Masiero and Nicolau, forthcoming). Consequently, we find that price is significant and presents a negative sign, being a dissuasive factor in the choice of activities. Its standard deviation parameter, however, is significant too, meaning that “price” has a differentiated effect among the individuals of the sample. This heterogeneous responsiveness to price supports the use of this variable as a segmentation criterion.

sec.title: Formation and Characterization of Segments
sec.p: Once we have estimated the price coefficients for each individual, we apply Ward’s cluster method to the matrix of these estimations of individual price parameter estimates. Applying the double explanation criteria of a minimum of 65% of the total variance, and of at least a 5% increase in variance when adding a new segment, we select four segments. Table 2 summarizes these results; the shaded area represents the number of segments selected according to individual price preferences.

caption.p: Determination of the Number of Segments

sec.p: As reflected in the ANOVA results, the segments identified are significantly distinct at a level of 0.001 (F = 1087.8; p < 0.001). This confirms the existence of differences in the individual price preference structures.

Once we have identified the segments according to the proposed criterion, we proceed to characterize them according to price sensitivity and various variables that describe the tourists and their behavior. Table 3 shows the segments formed according to “price sensitivity,” showing the averages of each segment and the global values for the whole sample. We also indicate distinct segments according to the Scheffé Test. This test shows that the four segments—across all of them—have different preferences for the dimension of “price sensitivity.”

caption.p: Characterization of the Segments through Price Sensitivities

sec.p: In general, segments 1, 2, and 3 present a negative posture toward prices, with segment 1 showing the highest negative effect—which in turn is the smallest segment—and segment 3 a moderately negative reaction to them. Observe that segment 4 has a positive sensitivity to price, meaning that they are predisposed to pay a higher price.

The four segments identified are finally analyzed with respect to individual characterization on demographics, tourist behavior, motivations, and activity participation. In particular, Table 4 reports the mean for the overall sample and for the four segments. As a test for capturing significant differences across the segments we also report (Table 4, last column) the chi-square statistic computed for each individual characteristic. (Test statistics for continuous variables “number of nights” and “holiday budget” rely on F test [ANOVA] and for all the other categorical variables chi-square test from contingency tables applies.)

tr.td: Being free to act how I feel
Feeling at home away from home
Using cable cars (for visiting panoramic sites and/or hiking)

sec.p: Looking at the chi-square test results, only two variables associated with demographics and three with activity participation are found to be statistically different among segments, and none of the variables characterizing tourist behavior shows a valid difference. In particular, regarding demographic characteristics, segment 1 has the highest concentration of German citizens and segment 2 shows the highest age average. Regarding activity participation, activities like “dining out,” “visiting museum and historical buildings,” and “lido” register significant differences with the highest frequency observed for segment 1, 4, and 2, respectively.

Turning to motivations expressed by tourists, 13 statements of 17 are found to be statistically different within the four segments. This finding shows that motivations have greater ability to segment tourist market than sociodemographics, which is in line with Bieger and Laesser (2002). In this context, it is interesting to note that tourists belonging to segment 4, who on average have a positive sensitivity to price, give more importance to motivations that commonly imply taking part in paid activities. In particular, higher values, compared to the first three segments, have been found, for example, for “experiencing new /different lifestyles,” “being entertained and having fun,” “trying new food,” and “visiting historical places,” though for the latter two, no statistical differences among the segments emerge from the data.7 On the contrary, segment 1, which has the highest price sensitivity (the most negative parameter), is characterized by tourists’ giving more importance to motivations that typically do not involve additional expenses, such as “being physically active,” “going to a sunny place,” “experiencing landscape and nature,” and “getting rest and relaxation.”

This result contributes to generalizability in terms of the power of motivations. As stated, the literature on tourist segmentation has found that motivations allow the analyst to better form segments than sociodemographics (Bieger and Laesser 2002). Specifically, our result helps enhance the idea that motivations not only are good for “finding segments” but also for “describing segments” obtained through individual price sensitivities to activities.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The effect of prices of tourism activities has a double role: on one hand, it is the only component of the destination marketing mix that brings about revenue as product, distribution, and promotion produce cost (Kotler, Bowen, and Makens 2006), and on the other, it is a determinant factor of tourist choice. On this account, identifying patterns of tourists with different degrees of sensitivities to prices would help destinations design an appropriate bundle of activities and have a clear definition of the segment they should try to promote. On this account, price sensitivity segmentation is certainly the primary objective of the article, with an important nuance: we are dealing with the formation of segments through price sensitivities related to activities at destination. While the literature on prices is immense and the literature on price sensitivity is reasonably large, when we turn to individual price sensitivities as raw inputs for segmenting the tourism market, the number of analyses is scarcer (e.g., Petrick 2005) and, to the authors’ knowledge, proposals of segmenting tourist markets through the use of “price sensitivities related to activities at destination” are exiguous.

This article has found tourist segments from individual price sensitivities to activities. Specifically, the results indicate that price is a dissuasive factor in the choice of activities (tourism activities behave as ordinary goods) but with a differentiated effect (as this dissuasiveness is not general for all individuals). Precisely, this heterogeneous responsiveness to price supports the use of price sensitivity as a segmentation criterion.

By applying Ward’s cluster method to the matrix of the estimations of the individual parameters estimations, we have identified four segments: three of them with negative effects of prices and one with a positive influence. This result is in accordance with the idea that price can sometimes be considered an attraction factor. In particular, segment 1 is the smallest segment, presents the strongest negative price effect and has the widest range of motivations rated above the mean, especially those motivations that do not necessary imply paid activities; segment 2 shows the second most negative price effect and the highest age average along with the highest participation to lido activities on the lakes; segment 3 has a moderate negative price effect close to zero, but still negative, and it is characterized by tourists rating “experiencing landscape and nature” below the average but seeking entertainment and fun; and segment 4, presents a positive price effect and, compared to the others, represents the youngest segment and a particular inclination on visiting museum and historical places and attracted by new/different lifestyles.

As for managerial implications, note that the analysis is based on the preferences of individual people, and preferences are key elements in the choice of activities. Moreover, the estimation of individual parameters (price sensitivities) allows the analyst to operate with precise information on each individual. At a time when people are increasingly demanding service provision adapted to their specific needs, knowledge of the profile of each individual allows organizations to offer the most suitable products. Identifying individuals with more or less predisposition to pay for a combination of activities is crucial for destination managers. In this way they can, first, know their clientele in terms of price preferences; second, develop appropriate products with the right set of activities; third, set “fair” prices (without incurring opportunity costs); and fourth, design promotional campaigns directed at the targeted group with the stress on the appropriate traits (e.g., regarding these promotional campaigns, as motivations have been especially relevant, once destinations have identified their “good segment” they can include the motivations of interest as a topic to form the message to be promoted).

The observation that motivations are correlated with price sensitivities has important managerial implications: (1) Detecting segments based on price sensitivities whose members have different preferences in terms of motivations allows DMOs to find tourism product designs—in terms of these motivations—that are adapted to and more likely to be preferred by tourists in this segment. (2) However, how can managers identify the members of a segment? As price-sensitivity-defined segments correlate with a certain group of motivations, considering this group of motivations will allow the indirect identification of people with a specific “price preference.” (3) Given that the core criterion to segment the tourism market is “individual price sensitivity,” pricing decisions will be made in full accordance with the segment’s preferences. (4) Aggregating people in a segment with similar motivations might imply putting together people who tend to like and seek activities in conformity with these motivations; this means that travel intermediaries can form tourism products containing such activities. (5) And despite the fact that segmentation allows the definition of different market segments that group consumers with shared behavior and needs and with a well-defined reaction to the availability of different products, nowadays there is increasing importance attached to personalized service for each client. More proactive consumers and an intense competition increase the demand for better service, something that is better adapted to their individual needs and, therefore, personalized. Customers expect to be treated as individual clients. This situation entails individual consideration of consumers and a one-by-one service, which gives more importance to the identification of individual preferences. This approach is the basic pillar of CRM (Customer Relationship Management) which is designed to create, strengthen, and maintain relationships between companies/destinations and their customers, in order to maximize income per customer. Therefore, the application of the segmentation strategy implies the detection of the most profitable customers to establish a close relationship with them, bearing in mind their needs and adapting products accordingly. In this regard, note that this article deals with the central element that determines how profitable a client is (i.e., individual price sensitivity), and at the same time, provides information on their internal aspects of the individual (the most meaningful being their motivations).

Note that this is a flexible approach, and one might go about segmenting tourism markets on the basis of price sensitivity in other situations and markets. Let us imagine that a travel agent or a hotel located in a destination has several combinations of activities available, each combination with different prices. The travel agent or the hotel just has to observe the alternative chosen and the activities that characterize each combination. Obviously, the combination chosen as well as the activities in each alternative are known by the travel agent and hotel; thus, surveys are not indisposed to learn the drivers that lead people to go for a specific combination.

Regarding study limitations, we should point out the following: (1) We base the analysis on a convenience sample, which a priori prevents us from easily making generalizations; note, however, that the explanatory ability of motivations does help support the extant literature on their superior “power” over sociodemographics. (2) The article is restricted to a set of variables. The core, central dimension is price; the others are just complementing the utility function. However, the more variables are used, the higher the likelihood of getting better estimates of the individual utility function. (3) Finally, the research application is restricted to one destination. Certainly, many segmentation studies are based on a single destination—especially, the so-called destination-specific studies in segmentation analyses based on individual preferences (Sarigöllü and Huang 2005)—but it is true that more evidence is needed to confirm the results obtained.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

Three interviewers speaking the main tourist languages (German, Italian, and English) conducted face-to-face interviews three days per week over two months, covering nine major touristic locations in Ticino.
Indeed, as noted by Hensher (2006), the evaluation of small differences in the attribute levels is difficult to estimate.
For details on the discrete choice model, refer to Train (2009).
For details on stated preference data and stated choice methods, refer to Louviere, Hensher, and Swait (2000).
For a discussion on Halton draws, see Train (2009).
The chi-square test for “trying new food” and “visiting historical places” is significant at alpha levels of 0.18 and 0.21, respectively.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Lorenzo Masiero, PhD, is a post-doc researcher at the Institute for Economic Research (IRE) at the University of Lugano. His research interests include tourism demand, transport demand, discrete choice models, stated choice experiments, experimental design, reference dependent behavior. He has published in international journals like Tourism Economics, Transportation Research Part A, Transportation, Transport Policy, European Journal of Transport and Infrastructure Research.

Juan L. Nicolau, PhD, is a professor of marketing at the University of Alicante. His research covers the analysis of tourist choice behavior and the assessment of firm value. His work has appeared in Strategic Management Journal, Omega, Journal of Travel Research, Annals of Tourism Research, Tourism Management, Tourism Economics, Tourism Geographies, European Journal of Operational Research, Journal of Business Research, European Journal of Marketing, among others.
